# Tales of tagging two "small" species...

---


class: left, top

.center[
## Round goby (*Neogobius melanostomus*)
]

.pull-left[.large[
- Invasive, movements unknown
- Innovasea V4, V5 (180 kHz)
- Goby size: 70 - 150 mm TL
- Lab study objective: 
  - Internal vs external, tag size
  - Tagging negatively affected survival
  - External tags- .red[high] shedding rates

class: left, top

.center[
## Cisco (*Coregonus artedi*)
]

.pull-left[.large[
- Goal
  - Re-establish population in Saginaw Bay
  - Stocking ongoing (juvenile)
  - Movements? Survival? Predation?
]
.large[
- Lab study - objective
  - Estimate survival
  - Determine appropriate tag size]
.large[
- Methods
  - V5-1x (4.3mm x 5.7 mm x 12.7 mm)
  - ~ 140-160 mm fish, Jordan River Fish Hatchery
  - Trial conducted at HBBS
  ]
  ]
  
.pull-right[.center[
<img src="images/juv_cisco.jpg" width="50%" height="50%"/>

<img src="images/V5_tag_pic.jpg" width="30%" height="30%"/>
]
]

---

class: left, top

.center[
## Cisco Laboratory Study
]

.pull-left[.large[
- Treatments
    - Acoustic - V5 tag + PIT tag
	- Control - no tags
	- PIT - pit tag
	- Sham- surgery + PIT tag
]
.large[
- Results
  - Control and PIT groups - .red[no mortality]
  - Sham and acoustic - .red[75% survival after 30 days]
  - dead fish- .red[infection around sutures]
- .large[.red[All fish (N = 120) held in 1 - 2m tank]]
]
]

.pull-right[.center[
<img src="images/cisco_survival_lab.png" width="70%" height="70%"/>

<img src="images/cisco_lab_mort_crop.png" width="60%" height="60%"/>
]
]

---

class: left, top

.center[
## Cisco - Saginaw Bay
]
.pull-left[
.large[
- Objectives
  - Determine proportion of cisco that disperse > 4 km in 4 weeks
  - Post-stocking survival
  ]
.large[
- Methods
  - V5D-1x tags (predation), N = 26
  - Surgery ~ 2 weeks prior to release at Jordan River National Hatchery
  - Length ~ 160 mm TL
  - 5-0 mono suture
  - TENS- immobilization
  ]
.large[
- Results
  - .red[Survival 100% to release (> 2 weeks, 3 hr truck)]
  ] 
]

# Observations from surgically implanting tags in small fish

---

class: left, top

.center[
## Observations from tagging round goby and juvenile cisco
]

.large[
- Equipment
  - Cradel
  - Freshwater supply- low volume
      - Motor control
      - Peristaltic pump
	  ]
  .large[
  - Sutures
    - Mono (absorbable, 5-0 reverse cut)
	- Braided (absorbable)- "Saw?", promote bacteria?
	]
	
.center[	
<img src="images/goby_surgery.png" width="25%" height="25%"/>
]

---

class: left, top

.center[
## Observations from tagging round goby and juvenile cisco
]

.large[
- Small fish =  small body cavity. Location of incision depends on morphology and space to implant tag.
- Thin and fragile body wall.  Sutures can easily pull through tissue when secured.  More sutures, low tension
 ]

.center[
<img src="images/sutured_goby.png" width="35%" height="35%"/>
<img src="images/RG_sore.png" width="35%" height="35%"/>
]
---

.center[
## Observations from tagging round goby and juvenile cisco
]

.large[
- Post-operative care
 - Water quality
 - Handling stress and tank stress = decreased survival
 - Low tank density- don't crowd
 - Release fish as soon as swimming on own
   - If holding fish after tagging 
     - Consider mild salt bath (0.25%) to help control infection
	]
	
.center[
<img src="images/goby_in_tank.png" width="35%" height="35%"/>
]
